The post Helsinki marks a year without traffic deaths, thanks to slower speeds and smarter streets first appeared on The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News.
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

Helsinki achieved something remarkable: a full year without a single traffic fatality. City and police officials confirmed the milestone this week, noting that the last fatal accident took place in early July 2024 in the Kontula district.

Authorities say such a stretch is unprecedented. “A lot of factors contributed to this, but speed limits are one of the most important,” explained Roni Utriainen, a traffic engineer with the city’s Urban Environment Division.

Slower speeds, safer streets

More than half of Helsinki’s streets now have a 30 km/h limit, a major shift from fifty years ago, when most were set at 50 km/h. Earlier this summer, the city decided to lower limits near schools to 30 km/h, with the change taking effect as the new academic year begins.

The reasoning is straightforward: slower speeds greatly reduce both the likelihood and severity of accidents.

Design, enforcement, and transit

Better street design has also played a major role. Helsinki has invested heavily in pedestrian and cycling infrastructure, created safer intersections, and added more crosswalk protections. Partnerships with traffic police have intensified, supported by a growing network of cameras and automated enforcement systems.

“Public transport in Helsinki is excellent, which reduces car use, and with it, the number of serious accidents,” Utriainen noted. Advances in vehicle technology have further boosted safety across all forms of personal transport.

The results go beyond fatalities. Over the past year, there were 277 injury-causing accidents in Helsinki. This is far fewer than the late 1980s, when the city regularly saw nearly 1,000 such incidents annually and up to 30 traffic deaths.

Decades of progress

The achievement is part of a long-term trend. The city’s current traffic safety strategy (2022–2026) focuses on protecting children, youth, pedestrians, and cyclists, using data-driven tools to plan safer crosswalks, improve intersections, and monitor traffic patterns.

“The direction has been positive for years,” Utriainen said, pointing out that 2019 also saw zero pedestrian deaths in Helsinki. He emphasized that credit belongs to everyone on the road— motorists, cyclists, and pedestrians alike.

Adapting to new challenges

One recent safety concern has been the rapid rise of electric scooters. “They became popular around five years ago, somewhat unexpectedly. But since then, many solutions have been put in place,” Utriainen explained.

Helsinki’s success aligns with the European Union’s “Vision Zero” policy, which aims for no traffic deaths by 2050. While the target may sound ambitious, Utriainen said it shapes daily decision-making: “We aim to assess all our decisions based on their long-term impact.”

articles.personality_title: Helsinki completes a year without any traffic deaths thanks to safer streets
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Helsinki, the capital of Finland, has worked for many years to make its roads safer. In the past, the city had many traffic accidents and deaths, but recent changes aimed to reduce these dangers.

**What happened** – In July 2024, Helsinki reached an important milestone: a full year passed without a single traffic death. City officials confirmed this, noting the last fatal accident was in early July 2023 in the Kontula district. The city lowered speed limits to 30 km/h on more than half of its streets and especially near schools. They also improved street designs, added safer crosswalks, and increased police enforcement using cameras and automated systems.

**Impact** – This achievement shows that slower speeds and smarter street planning can save lives. Fewer accidents happened overall—277 injury accidents in the past year compared to nearly 1,000 in the 1980s. Helsinki’s strong public transport and safer roads for walking and cycling also helped reduce car use and serious crashes.

**What's next step** – Helsinki will continue its traffic safety plan through 2026, focusing on protecting children, pedestrians, and cyclists. The city will keep using data to improve intersections and monitor traffic. They also plan to manage new challenges like the rise of electric scooters. The city’s work supports the European Union’s goal of zero traffic deaths by 2050.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By lowering speeds, redesigning streets, and enforcing rules, Helsinki has shown that it is possible to go a full year without any traffic deaths.
articles.personality_title_fr: Helsinki atteint un an sans aucun décès sur la route grâce à des rues plus sûres
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Helsinki, la capitale de la Finlande, travaille depuis des années à rendre ses routes plus sûres. Autrefois, la ville comptait de nombreux accidents et décès, mais des changements récents visaient à réduire ces dangers.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En juillet 2024, Helsinki a atteint un jalon important : une année entière sans aucun décès sur la route. Les autorités ont confirmé que le dernier accident mortel avait eu lieu début juillet 2023 dans le quartier de Kontula. La ville a abaissé les limites de vitesse à 30 km/h sur plus de la moitié de ses rues, en particulier près des écoles. Elle a aussi amélioré la conception des rues, ajouté des passages piétons plus sûrs et renforcé la surveillance policière avec des caméras et des systèmes automatiques.

**Impact** – Cette réussite montre que des vitesses plus lentes et une meilleure organisation des rues peuvent sauver des vies. Le nombre d’accidents a fortement diminué : 277 accidents avec blessés cette année, contre près de 1 000 dans les années 1980. Le bon réseau de transports en commun et des routes plus sûres pour les piétons et cyclistes ont également aidé à réduire l’usage de la voiture et les accidents graves.

**Prochaine étape** – Helsinki poursuivra son plan de sécurité routière jusqu’en 2026, en mettant l’accent sur la protection des enfants, piétons et cyclistes. La ville continuera à utiliser les données pour améliorer les intersections et surveiller le trafic. Elle prévoit aussi de gérer de nouveaux défis comme la montée des trottinettes électriques. Ce travail soutient l’objectif de l’Union européenne d’éliminer les décès sur la route d’ici 2050.

**En une phrase** – En abaissant les vitesses, en repensant les rues et en renforçant les règles, Helsinki a prouvé qu’il est possible de passer une année entière sans aucun décès sur la route.
articles.personality_title_es: Helsinki cumple un año sin muertes de tráfico gracias a calles más seguras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Helsinki, la capital de Finlandia, ha trabajado durante muchos años para hacer sus calles más seguras. En el pasado, la ciudad tenía muchos accidentes y muertes de tráfico, pero cambios recientes buscaron reducir estos peligros.

**Qué pasó** – En julio de 2024, Helsinki alcanzó un logro importante: un año completo sin ninguna muerte en accidentes de tráfico. Las autoridades confirmaron que el último accidente fatal ocurrió a principios de julio de 2023 en el distrito de Kontula. La ciudad redujo los límites de velocidad a 30 km/h en más de la mitad de sus calles, especialmente cerca de las escuelas. También mejoraron el diseño de las calles, añadieron pasos peatonales más seguros y aumentaron la vigilancia policial con cámaras y sistemas automáticos.

**Impacto** – Este logro muestra que reducir la velocidad y planear mejor las calles puede salvar vidas. El número de accidentes disminuyó mucho: 277 accidentes con lesiones en el último año, comparado con casi 1,000 en los años 80. El buen transporte público y calles más seguras para peatones y ciclistas ayudaron a reducir el uso de autos y accidentes graves.

**Próximo paso** – Helsinki seguirá con su plan de seguridad vial hasta 2026, enfocándose en proteger a niños, peatones y ciclistas. La ciudad usará datos para mejorar las intersecciones y controlar el tráfico. También planea enfrentar nuevos retos como el aumento de los patinetes eléctricos. Este esfuerzo apoya la meta de la Unión Europea de cero muertes en accidentes para 2050.

**En una frase** – Al bajar la velocidad, rediseñar las calles y reforzar las reglas, Helsinki demostró que es posible pasar un año entero sin muertes en el tráfico.

articles.title: “EU4Schools” also in the north of Albania, the kindergarten and nursery in Rubik are being rebuilt
articles.summary: The program "EU4Schools" is funded by the European Union with 75 million euros and is implemented by UNDP in Albania in cooperation with the Albanian government.
articles.content:
The program “EU4Schools” is funded by the European Union with 75 million euros and is implemented by UNDP in Albania in cooperation with the Albanian government.

The Municipality of Mirditë in northern Albania is one of the 11 municipalities benefiting from the “EU for Schools” program.

In the Administrative Unit of Rubik of this municipality, “EU4Schools” has made it possible to rebuild the kindergarten & nursery “Bleta Punëtore,” bringing hope and high standards through modern educational infrastructure.

For about 2 and a half years now, this rebuilt facility has welcomed children from Rubik and teaching staff in contemporary spaces with thermal insulation, efficient electrical and hydro-sanitary installations, heating-cooling systems, and fire protection, security camera systems, ramps for access for persons with disabilities, efficient outdoor lighting, etc.

The “EU4Schools” program is funded by the European Union with 75 million euros and is implemented by UNDP in Albania in cooperation with the Albanian government.

So far, in the context of this project, 61 out of 63 educational facilities have been completed in 11 municipalities affected by the 2019 earthquake, impacting the lives of over 25,000 children, students, and teachers. (August 15)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant EU-funded program rebuilding educational facilities in Albania, benefiting over 25,000 children, students, and teachers by providing modern, safe, and accessible infrastructure. This has a broad positive impact on education and community recovery after the 2019 earthquake, with clear substance and meaningful scope.
articles.personality_title: EU-funded program rebuilds kindergarten in northern Albania with modern facilities
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – After a strong earthquake hit Albania in 2019, many schools and kindergartens were damaged, especially in the northern regions. The European Union (EU) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) started a project to help rebuild these educational places.

**What happened** – The “EU4Schools” program, funded with 75 million euros by the EU and carried out by UNDP with the Albanian government, has rebuilt the kindergarten and nursery named “Bleta Punëtore” in the town of Rubik, northern Albania. This facility has been open for about two and a half years and offers modern classrooms with heating, cooling, fire safety, security cameras, and ramps for children with disabilities.

**Impact** – This rebuilt kindergarten provides a safe, comfortable, and accessible place for children to learn and grow. It is one of 61 educational buildings restored in 11 municipalities affected by the earthquake. The program has helped over 25,000 children, students, and teachers by improving their learning environment.

**What’s next step** – The program will continue to support schools in other areas damaged by the earthquake until all educational facilities are restored. This will help communities recover and ensure children have good places to study.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s “EU4Schools” program is restoring safe and modern educational spaces in northern Albania, improving learning conditions for thousands of children after the 2019 earthquake.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un programme financé par l’UE reconstruit une maternelle dans le nord de l’Albanie avec des installations modernes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Après un fort tremblement de terre en Albanie en 2019, de nombreuses écoles et maternelles ont été endommagées, notamment dans le nord. L’Union européenne (UE) et le Programme des Nations unies pour le développement (PNUD) ont lancé un projet pour reconstruire ces lieux d’éducation.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le programme « EU4Schools », financé par l’UE à hauteur de 75 millions d’euros et réalisé par le PNUD avec le gouvernement albanais, a reconstruit la maternelle et crèche « Bleta Punëtore » dans la ville de Rubik, au nord de l’Albanie. Cette structure est ouverte depuis environ deux ans et demi et offre des salles modernes avec chauffage, climatisation, sécurité incendie, caméras de surveillance et rampes pour enfants en situation de handicap.

**Impact** – Cette maternelle reconstruite offre un lieu sûr, confortable et accessible pour que les enfants puissent apprendre et grandir. C’est l’un des 61 bâtiments éducatifs restaurés dans 11 municipalités touchées par le tremblement de terre. Le programme a aidé plus de 25 000 enfants, élèves et enseignants en améliorant leur environnement d’apprentissage.

**Prochaine étape** – Le programme continuera à soutenir les écoles dans d’autres zones endommagées par le tremblement de terre jusqu’à ce que toutes les structures éducatives soient restaurées. Cela aidera les communautés à se remettre et garantira de bons lieux d’étude pour les enfants.

**En une phrase** – Le programme « EU4Schools » de l’UE restaure des espaces éducatifs sûrs et modernes dans le nord de l’Albanie, améliorant les conditions d’apprentissage pour des milliers d’enfants après le tremblement de terre de 2019.
articles.personality_title_es: Programa financiado por la UE reconstruye jardín de niños en el norte de Albania con instalaciones modernas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Después de un fuerte terremoto en Albania en 2019, muchas escuelas y jardines de niños resultaron dañados, especialmente en el norte. La Unión Europea (UE) y el Programa de las Naciones Unidas para el Desarrollo (PNUD) iniciaron un proyecto para ayudar a reconstruir estos lugares educativos.

**Qué pasó** – El programa “EU4Schools”, financiado con 75 millones de euros por la UE y ejecutado por el PNUD junto con el gobierno albanés, reconstruyó el jardín de niños y guardería llamado “Bleta Punëtore” en la ciudad de Rubik, en el norte de Albania. Esta instalación lleva abierta unos dos años y medio y ofrece aulas modernas con calefacción, refrigeración, seguridad contra incendios, cámaras de vigilancia y rampas para niños con discapacidades.

**Impacto** – Este jardín de niños reconstruido ofrece un lugar seguro, cómodo y accesible para que los niños aprendan y crezcan. Es uno de los 61 edificios educativos restaurados en 11 municipios afectados por el terremoto. El programa ha ayudado a más de 25,000 niños, estudiantes y profesores mejorando su ambiente de aprendizaje.

**Próximo paso** – El programa continuará apoyando escuelas en otras áreas dañadas por el terremoto hasta que todas las instalaciones educativas estén restauradas. Esto ayudará a las comunidades a recuperarse y asegurará buenos lugares para que los niños estudien.

**Una frase para llevar** – El programa “EU4Schools” de la UE está restaurando espacios educativos seguros y modernos en el norte de Albania, mejorando las condiciones de aprendizaje para miles de niños después del terremoto de 2019.
